questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a history of hypertension is diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) after a CT scan reveals a 5 cm tumor confined to the right kidney. His renal function is normal, and there is no evidence of metastasis. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Investigations for RCC:

Ultrasound (USG)

Initial Imaging

Helps distinguish between solid and cystic masses

Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT)

Investigation of choice for diagnosis and staging.

MRI

Superior at detecting tumor infiltration into the vein wall and the level of thrombus.

Investigation of choice for detecting tumor thrombus

Chest Imaging (CT or X-ray), Bone Scan

To rule out metastases.

Renal Biopsy

Not routinely performed due to the risk of seeding and the high diagnostic accuracy of imaging.

Treatment of RCC: RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy(Option A): Involves removing only the tumor while preserving the remainder of the kidney.

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim.

Indications: Larger tumors or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation: Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumors(T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is incidentally found to have a horseshoe kidney during an abdominal CT scan. She has no symptoms. Which of the following complications is she at highest risk for developing?

A 45-year-old woman with a history of tuberous sclerosis complex with angiomyolipoma (AML) presents with a sudden onset of severe left flank pain. On examination, she is hypotensive and has a tender left flank. Imaging reveals a large hemorrhage in the left kidney extending into the perirenal space. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Angiomyolipomas (AMLs)

Arise from
  • Perivascular epithelioid cells

Types
  • Most renal AMLs are asymptomatic, discovered incidentally on imaging.
  • Sporadic AMLs: Present in the 4th-6th decades, typically small, solitary, and slow-growing.
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Present earlier (3rd-4th decades), larger, multiple, bilateral, and tend to grow.

Symptoms

  • Common symptoms: Abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and impaired kidney function, usually due to hemorrhage.
  • Hemorrhage: Severe complication.
  • Wunderlich syndrome: nontraumatic kidney hemorrhage.
  • Risk factors for hemorrhage: AML size (>6 cm), increased vascularity, large intralesional aneurysms (>5 mm), and exophytic growth pattern.

Risk Factors for AML Complications
  • Pregnancy: Increased risk of hemorrhage due to hormonal changes, increased blood volume, and cardiac output.
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Higher risk of CKD and ESKD, often due to nephrectomy or embolization.
  • Epithelioid AMLs: Potential for malignant transformation, metastasis, and local recurrence.

Diagnosis

  
  • CT: (Investigation of choice) Presence of intralesional fat.
  • Ultrasound: Bright echogenic mass lesion on account of the high fat content. Used for monitoring AML size.
  • MRI: T1 and T2 hyperintensity with enhancement on gadolinium administration. In Phase/opposed phase imaging: India ink artifact. Useful mainly in fat poor AML.
  • Biopsy: Indicated if diagnosis is uncertain via imaging or malignancy is suspected.
  • Immunocytochemical analysis: Useful for differentiating AML from RCC, using markers like HMB-45 and melan-A.

Treatment
  • Observation: Suitable for tumors <4 cm
  • Nephron-Sparing Surgery(Partial nephrectomy): Preferred for larger tumors or those with a high risk of bleeding
  • Angioembolization: Main treatment for acute hemorrhage, involves blocking blood flow to the tumor.
  • Medications: mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and sirolimus are useful, especially in cases associated with tuberous sclerosis complex.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with an incidental finding of a renal mass on imaging. The mass shows an enhancing appearance on cross-sectional imaging with a central stellate scar. A biopsy is inconclusive, and the mass is surgically removed. Histopathological examination reveals granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm within the tumor cells, negative for cytokeratin 7. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Renal Oncocytoma

Definition & Prevalence
  • Benign renal tumor with oncocytes, characterized by granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Accounts for ~5% of all renal tumors.

Clinical Presentation
  • Typically occurs in the seventh decade of life, more common in males.
  • Can coexist with RCC in ~10% of cases

Diagnosis
  • CECT: (Investigation of choice): Presents as an enhancing mass, while not pathognomonic, can suggest oncocytoma:
    • Central Stellate Scarring: The presence of a star-shaped scar within the tumor.
    • Spoke Wheel Appearance: A characteristic pattern observed during the angiographic phase of imaging.

Confirmation of Diagnosis
  • Confirmed post-surgical removal and histopathological examination of oncocytes.
  • Differentiation from chromophobe RCC (eosinophilic variant) may require immunohistochemistry, where chromophobe RCC stains positive for cytokeratin 7 and oncocytoma is positive.

Treatment & Prognosis
  • Nephron-sparing surgery (partial nephrectomy) is the preferred treatment due to its benign nature.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of smoking presents with a sudden onset of headaches and visual disturbances. A CT scan shows a 5 cm mass in the left kidney. Which of the following is most likely associated with her condition?

A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a large renal tumor and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of Wilms tumor. Which of the following statements regarding Wilms tumor is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemotherapy is contraindicated in Wilms tumor due to the young age of the patients

options.label: B
options.text: The most common site of metastasis in patients with Wilms tumor is the Liver.

options.label: C
options.text: A multimodal approach including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation is typically used.

options.label: D
options.text: The route of spread is mostly lymphatic for metastasis of tumor foci.

questions.correct_answer: C. A multimodal approach including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation is typically used.
questions.explanation:
Clinical Presentation

Triad:

  • Asymptomatic abdominal mass (MC presentation)
  • Fever (disappears after tumor resection)
  • Hematuria (Gross/Microscopic)

Rarely: Pain

Investigations

USG- Primary investigation

CECT- Investigation of choice.

MRI - For better soft tissue visualization.

Treatment

Treatment approach varies based on stage and histology-

Multimodal approach

  • Surgery: Radical nephrectomy or nephron-sparing surgery
  • Chemotherapy: VCD regimen (Option A)

Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Dactinomycin/Doxorubicin

  • Radiation therapy: For higher stages or unfavorable histology

Staging

I. Disease confined to the kidney and completely resectable

II. Tumor extends beyond the kidney but can be excised completely

IlI. Residual disease after resection with positive lymph nodes and massive spillage

IV. Blood-borne metastasis

V. Bilateral disease

Prognosis

Most important Prognostic Factor - Histology > Stage

Metastasis

Mainly through a hematogenous route into: (Option D)

  • Lungs (MC) (Option B)
  • Liver
  • Bones (Rarely)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease?

options.label: A
options.text: The disease involves a mutation in the PKD1 and PKD2 genes on chromosomes 4 and 16 respectively

options.label: B
options.text: Hypertension is the most common manifestation

options.label: C
options.text: Cysts can be seen in the organs such as the ovary, and pancreas in patients with ADPKD

options.label: D
options.text: The most common extrarenal manifestation is polycystic liver disease

questions.correct_answer: A. The disease involves a mutation in the PKD1 and PKD2 genes on chromosomes 4 and 16 respectively
questions.explanation:
Definition

Characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys.

Inheritance
  • Autosomal Dominant
  • Involvement of chromosome 16 (PKD1) and 4 (PKD2)
  • Abnormal protein-Polycystin
  • Both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts

Pathogenesis

  • Both kidneys are replaced by multiple cysts
  • The kidney loses its function of the concentration of urine
  • Cysts in kidney → Compression of blood vessels → Activation of RAAS → Hypertension

Clinical Features (Intrarenal)
  • Most common manifestation is hypertension (Option B)
  • Polyuria, Nocturia, Hematuria
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Chronic renal failure (Usually in the 5th to 6th decade)
  • Any compression in the pelvicalyceal system will lead to HIS (Hydronephrosis; Infection; Stone) → Hematuria

Clinical Features (Extrarenal)
  • Polycystic Liver Disease (Most common) (Option D)
  • Cyst in Ovary, Pancreas, Spleen (Option C)
  • Berry Aneurysm
  • Mitral Valve prolapse
  • The most common cause of death is cardiovascular Disorders

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with right-sided flank pain and persistent hematuria. An intravenous urogram is done and given below. What is the definitive management of this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Surgical repositioning of the ureter

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a cystic dilation near the ureteral orifice within the bladder. Which of the following best describes the underlying condition?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric urology clinic by her mother, who reports that the child has "never been dry" since birth. The mother notes that urine dribbles continuously via the vagina, but the child can also pass urine normally. An intravenous urogram is performed which is attached below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Ectopic ureter from duplicated collecting system

questions.correct_answer: C. Ectopic ureter from duplicated collecting system
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology
  • MC congenital anomaly of the upper urinary tract
  • Usually unilateral, common on the left side; More common in females

Types
  • Incomplete duplication
    • Bifid ureter
  • Complete duplication
    • Weigert Meyer’s Rule- Upper pole ureter is caudal and medial compared to lower pole ureter.

Clinical Features
  • In Males
    • Recurrent infections
  • In Females
    • Continuous incontinence (dribbling) with normal voiding pattern

Investigations

IOC for Dx is IVP-

Complications

  • For complete duplication
    • Upper pole ureter- Ureterocele
    • Lower pole ureter - VUR (due to short intravesical length)
  • For incomplete duplication, there is reno-renal reflux resulting in:
    • Infection
    • Stone formation
    • Hydronephrosis

Treatment
  • For upper pole ureter: Excision + Reimplantation into bladder
  • For lower pole ureter: Ureterovesicoplasty (strengthening of uretero-vesical junction)
  • Reimplantation of the ectopic ureter
  • If there is upper pole hydronephrosis with no function: Upper pole nephrectomy should be performed.

Radiological Signs
  • Yo-Yo reflux: Reflux of contrast in both limbs of the ureter on retrograde pyelogram in incomplete duplication
  • Drooping lily sign: Seen in duplication with malrotation pelvis

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and a palpable kidney mass in the loin region. Further, the patient is diagnosed with vesicoureteric reflux on both sides. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the management of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Most cases resolve spontaneously without treatment

options.label: B
options.text: The investigation of choice is Intravenous Pyelogram

options.label: C
options.text: Symptomatic cases require surgical correction via ureteric reimplantation

options.label: D
options.text: Severe cases may require nephrectomy and renal transplantation

questions.correct_answer: B. The investigation of choice is Intravenous Pyelogram
questions.explanation:
Causes
  • Congenital: Commonly associated with posterior urethral valve
  • Acquired: Trauma due to surgery or intervention

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent UTI and Pyelonephritis
  • Palpable mass in the loin
  • Renal failure in bilateral cases

Complications

Renal scarring if not managed in symptomatic patients

Investigations
  • Micturating cystourethrogram (IOC)
  • Intravenous urography
  • Urine microscopy and C/S
  • Blood urea and serum creatinine

Treatment

Grade I to III- Antibiotic Prophylaxis as it resolves spontaneously in most patients. (Option A)

Grade IV to V- Antibiotics + Surgery

Only symptomatic patients require surgical correction via ureteric reimplantation. (Option B)

Surgery:

  • Ureterovesicoplasty
  • Ureteric reimplantation (Lich-Gregoir technique)
  • STING Operation (Endoscopic)

Severe cases may require nephrectomy and renal transplantation. (Option D)
